title: Hierarchical Bayesian Models
description: Understanding hierarchical Bayesian models and their role in modeling complex systems with multiple levels of abstraction.
learning_objectives: Apply hierarchical models to complex data

content.overview: Hierarchical Bayesian models organize parameters into multiple levels, allowing information to be shared across groups while accounting for individual variation. They provide a natural framework for modeling complex systems with multiple levels of abstraction.

mathematical_structure.hierarchical_form: p(θ, φ | x) = p(x | θ) p(θ | φ) p(φ)
mathematical_structure.levels: Data level → Parameters level → Hyperparameters level
mathematical_structure.partial_pooling: θ_i drawn from population distribution with parameters φ
mathematical_structure.shrinkage: Individual estimates pulled toward population mean

types_of_hierarchies.description: Parameters drawn i.i.d. from population distribution
types_of_hierarchies.example: Student test scores across multiple schools
types_of_hierarchies.model: θ_j ~ N(μ, σ²), μ ~ N(μ₀, σ₀²)
θ_{ijk} ~ N(θ_{jk}, σ₁²), θ_{jk} ~ N(θ_k, σ₂²), θ_k ~ N(μ, σ₃²)

types_of_hierarchies.example: Patients treated by different doctors in different hospitals

benefits_of_hierarchical_modeling.information_sharing: Information flows between groups through hyperparameters
benefits_of_hierarchical_modeling.flexibility: Models adapt to different levels of variation

examples.name: School Performance Modeling
examples.description: Estimate school quality while accounting for uncertainty
examples.data: Test scores from students in multiple schools
examples.model: y_{ij} ~ N(θ_j, σ²), θ_j ~ N(μ, τ²), μ ~ N(μ₀, σ₀²)
examples.interpretation: School effects partially pooled toward population mean

examples.name: Clinical Trial Analysis
examples.description: Multi-center clinical trials with varying effects
examples.model: Treatment effect varies by hospital but shares population parameters
examples.interpretation: Account for hospital-specific effects while estimating overall treatment

inference_methods.analytical_methods: When conjugate priors available at all levels

connections_to_active_inference.empirical_priors: Higher levels provide constraints on lower levels
connections_to_active_inference.learning: Hierarchical belief updating and structure learning

design_principles.prior_specification: Choose appropriate priors at each level

interactive_exercises.description: Design hierarchical models for different datasets
Analyze shrinkage effects in hierarchical models

common_misconceptions.clarification: Only when data supports multiple levels of variation
Depends on the amount of data per group
Can use analytical methods when appropriate

further_reading.author: Sudipto Banerjee et al.
